discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Global, relational -> Spanner

Selected Answer: A
sql(relational) eliminate B and C, muliregional eliminate D

A.
Bigtable would not be a valid choice. BigQuery lends itself to OLAP not OLTP. Cloud SQL could not scale to multiple regions. It’s Spanner. A.

A: Use Cloud *** Spanner to deploy the database.
Cloud Spanner is a fully managed, mission-critical, relational database service that offers transactional consistency at global scale, automatic, synchronous replication for high availability, and support for two SQL dialects: Google Standard SQL (ANSI 2011 with extensions) and PostgreSQL.

questions.question_text: You are designing a new gaming application that uses a highly transactional relational database to store player authentication and inventory data in Google Cloud. You want to launch the game in multiple regions. What should you do?

choices.D: Use Cloud SQL with a regional read replica to deploy the database.
choices.B: Use Bigtable with clusters in multiple regions to deploy the database
choices.C: Use BigQuery to deploy the database
choices.A: Use Cloud Spanner to deploy the database.

choices.C: Use zonal Cloud SQL without high availability (HA).
choices.A: Use Cloud SQL with cross-region replicas.
choices.D: Use Cloud Spanner in a regional configuration.
choices.B: Use high availability (HA) Cloud SQL with multiple zones.

discussion.content:
D - spanner
ABC it is about Cloud SQL and the options don't offer anything to improve writing latency

Selected Answer: C
Another metric to note is that the latency for regional persistent disk with solid-state drives (SSD) is higher than it would be for a zonal persistent disk with SSD.
https://cloud.google.com/sql/docs/mysql/high-availability#ha-performance

comments.content: I think is D. A only increase the HA

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
multiples zonas has more latency

Selected Answer: D
The only one with write latency is regional Spanner
Correct answer is D - Use Cloud Spanner in a regional configuration.

Selected Answer: D
its Cloud SQL vs Spanner . Spanner has advantage in writing latency

A, B, C. replicas and HA will help in improving read latency only. Cloud SQL enables customers to implement horizontal scaling of read-only workloads using read replicas. It might degrade the write latency.
D. Spanner satisfies the requirement without sacrificing availability

Selected Answer: D
I think D.

Selected Answer: D
Spanner has higher write latency than other options

Selected Answer: D
D: just choose Cloud Spanner over Cloud SQL

Selected Answer: D
A and B add latency. C screams of an anti-pattern to me (no HA). Spanner satisfies the requirement without sacrificing availability, so D.

questions.question_text: You are designing a database strategy for a new web application in one region. You need to minimize write latency. What should you do?

choices.B: Migrate to Bare Metal Solution for Oracle.
choices.D: Migrate to Google Cloud VMware Engine

questions.question_text: You are running a large, highly transactional application on Oracle Real Application Cluster (RAC) that is multi-tenant and uses shared storage. You need a solution that ensures high-performance throughput and a low-latency connection between applications and databases. The solution must also support existing Oracle features and provide ease of migration to Google Cloud. What should you do?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
BMS for Oracle

B.
Oracle is neither licensed nor supported in GCE. The only platform which supports RAC and all existing Oracle features is BMS.

Selected Answer: B
B for sure
B: Migrate to Bare Metal Solution ***** for Oracle.

comments.content: I agree with u. The answer is B

discussion.content:
B.
Firestore is a NoSQL database. Eliminate A. You could migrate to Spanner leveraging the PostgreSQL dialect, but costs need to be minimized so that wouldn’t be the cheapest option. Especially since the load doesn’t justify Spanner. Again, you could migrate like-for-like to a GCE VM, but that defeats minimizing the migration effort. The cheapest and easiest way to migrate would be Database Migration Service to Cloud SQL for PostgreSQL.

Selected Answer: B
Totally B

Selected Answer: B
Migrate to CloudSQL
B: Migrate the existing database to Cloud SQL for PostgreSQL.

questions.question_text: You are choosing a new database backend for an existing application. The current database is running PostgreSQL on an on-premises VM and is managed by a database administrator and operations team. The application data is relational and has light traffic. You want to minimize costs and the migration effort for this application. What should you do?

choices.C: Migrate the existing database to Cloud Spanner.
choices.A: Migrate the existing database to Firestore.
choices.B: Migrate the existing database to Cloud SQL for PostgreSQL.
choices.D: Migrate the existing database to PostgreSQL running on Compute Engine.

choices.C: Migrate the application to Google Cloud, and use Identity and Access Management (IAM).
choices.D: Use Google Workspace Password Sync to replicate passwords into Google Cloud.
choices.B: Ask existing users to set their Google password to match their corporate password.
choices.A: Use workload identity federation to impersonate a service account.

questions.question_text: Your organization is currently updating an existing corporate application that is running in another public cloud to access managed database services in Google Cloud. The application will remain in the other public cloud while the database is migrated to Google Cloud. You want to follow Google-recommended practices for authentication. You need to minimize user disruption during the migration. What should you do?

discussion.content:
A.
Updating passwords represents user disruption. Eliminate B. Eliminate C for the same reason. D doesn’t make sense, leaves A. From Google’s documentation, “Traditionally, applications running outside Google Cloud can use service account keys to access Google Cloud resources. However, service account keys are powerful credentials, and can present a security risk if they are not managed correctly.

With identity federation, you can use Identity and Access Management (IAM) to grant external identities IAM roles, including the ability to impersonate service accounts. This approach eliminates the maintenance and security burden associated with service account keys.”
https://cloud.google.com/iam/docs/workload-identity-federation

Selected Answer: A
https://cloud.google.com/iam/docs/workload-identity-federation

Selected Answer: A
With identity federation, you can use Identity and Access Management (IAM) to grant external identities IAM roles, including the ability to impersonate service accounts. This lets you access resources directly, using a short-lived access token, and eliminates the maintenance and security burden associated with service account keys.

A: Use workload identity ***** federation to impersonate a service account.
Use identity federation to access resources from AWS, access resources from Microsoft Azure, access resources from an OIDC provider, or access resources from a SAML 2.0 provider. Learn how to manage workload identity pools using the Google Cloud CLI or the REST API.
